intro: Daucus carota var. herculeus, commonly known as the giant parsnip, is a variant of the common parsley plant. It is characterized by its large, heart-shaped leaves that can grow up to 30 centimeters in diameter. The plant produces yellow flowers in umbels, which are typical of the Apiaceae family. Its roots are typically white and can be quite thick, though they are not commonly harvested for culinary use. This variety is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of climates.
